caseNotes.primaryNoteText:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Morbid obesity with comorbidities

PROCEDURE: Laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass with concurrent paraesophageal hernia repair

INDICATIONS: The patient has morbid obesity with BMI of 47.3 kg/m². Multiple weight loss attempts have failed. Patient meets criteria for bariatric surgery with obesity-related comorbidities including type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and sleep apnea.

DESCRIPTION: The patient underwent laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass. Five laparoscopic ports were placed. The stomach was divided using a linear stapler to create a small gastric pouch. A Roux-en-Y limb was created with gastrojejunostomy and jejunojejunostomy anastomoses. A large paraesophageal hernia was identified and repaired during the procedure. The hernia sac was reduced and the crural repair was performed with non-absorbable sutures. Mesh reinforcement was placed. A central venous catheter was placed in the right internal jugular vein under ultrasound guidance for intraoperative monitoring and fluid management. Good blood return obtained. The procedure was completed without complications.

additionalNotes.content:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Morbid obesity scheduled for bariatric surgery

HISTORY: Patient has morbid obesity with BMI of 47.3 kg/m². Multiple weight loss attempts have failed. Patient meets criteria for bariatric surgery with obesity-related comorbidities. Patient has poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus with recent HbA1c of 9.2%. Currently on metformin and insulin therapy. Frequent episodes of hyperglycemia requiring adjustment of medications. Patient has essential hypertension currently managed with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Blood pressure readings have been elevated despite medication compliance. Patient has severe obstructive sleep apnea confirmed by overnight polysomnography. AHI of 42 events per hour. Currently uses CPAP therapy nightly.

PREOPERATIVE WORKUP: Preoperative 12-lead ECG was obtained prior to surgery. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with rate 78 bpm. No acute changes. Patient cleared for surgery from cardiac standpoint. CT scan demonstrates a large paraesophageal hernia with significant portion of stomach herniated into the thoracic cavity. No evidence of obstruction or strangulation.

SURGICAL PATHOLOGY REPORT

CLINICAL HISTORY: Morbid obesity, gastric bypass surgery

GROSS DESCRIPTION: The specimen consists of gastric fundus tissue measuring 2.5 x 1.8 x 0.8 cm. The tissue is tan-pink and soft.

MICROSCOPIC DESCRIPTION: Sections show chronic gastritis with moderate inflammatory infiltrate consisting of lymphocytes and plasma cells. The gastric mucosa shows mild reactive changes. No evidence of malignancy is identified. H. pylori organisms are not identified on routine staining.

DIAGNOSIS: Gastric tissue with chronic gastritis, no evidence of malignancy

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

PROCEDURE: Laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass with paraesophageal hernia repair

HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications. Postoperative course was uncomplicated. Patient was started on clear liquids on postoperative day 1 and advanced to full liquids on day 2. Pain was well controlled with oral medications. Patient was ambulating independently and vital signs remained stable.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: Patient discharged home on postoperative day 2 in stable condition. Follow-up scheduled in 1 week for wound check and dietary counseling. Patient instructed on bariatric diet progression and given educational materials.

POSTOPERATIVE DAY 1 PROGRESS NOTE

Subjective: Patient reports minimal pain, rates 3/10. Tolerating clear liquids well. No nausea or vomiting.

Objective: Vital signs stable. Afebrile. Incisions clean, dry, and intact. Abdomen soft, non-distended. Bowel sounds present.

Assessment: Postoperative day 1 status post laparoscopic gastric bypass with hernia repair. Patient doing well.

Plan: Continue clear liquids. Advance to full liquids if tolerated. Continue pain management. Ambulation as tolerated.
